q1.explanation: DevOps emerged because silos between development and operations caused slow, error-prone releases
common_mistakes: A: Too narrow - not just about programming languages
C: Cloud providers are a tool, not the core problem
D: Hardware wasn't the primary issue

q2.explanation: Continuous Integration means developers integrate code frequently (multiple times per day) into a shared repository
common_mistakes: B: Quarterly integration is traditional waterfall
C: Integration in production is dangerous

q3.explanation: Traditional IT typically deployed quarterly or yearly, leading to large, risky releases
common_mistakes: A, B: Multiple times per day or daily is DevOps/elite performance
D: Hourly is even more frequent than most elite performers

q4.explanation: Toil is manual, repetitive, automatable work that doesn't add value
common_mistakes: B: Not all work is toil - creative, strategic work is valuable
C: Difficult work can be valuable if it's not repetitive
D: Toil exists across all teams, not just operations

q5.explanation: The three pillars of DevOps are People, Process, Technology (in that order of importance)
common_mistakes: A: These are tools, not pillars
D: These are teams/roles, not pillars

q6.explanation: DevOps is primarily about culture and practices, not tools. Tools enable DevOps but culture makes it work.

q7.explanation: Automation eliminates toil, not jobs. People move to higher-value work like innovation and improvement.

q8.explanation: Blameless post-mortems focus on learning from failures and improving systems, not punishing individuals.

q9.explanation: DevOps means shared responsibility between Dev and Ops, not eliminating Ops roles. 'You build it, you run it' doesn't mean no Ops engineers.

q10.explanation: DORA research found elite performers deploy 208x more frequently than low performers, with LOWER failure rates (counterintuitive but true).

key_concepts: Silos between Dev and Ops teams
q11.good_answer_example: DevOps emerged because traditional IT couldn't keep up with business demands. Development and Operations worked in silos, leading to slow releases (quarterly or yearly), manual processes prone to errors, and long wait times. Meanwhile, competitors who adopted DevOps practices were shipping features faster, creating competitive pressure.
q11.minimum_for_full_credit: Mentions silos, slow releases, and business pressure

key_concepts: Lead time = total time from start to finish
Most time is usually waiting, not working
Matters because wait time is waste
q13.good_answer_example: Lead time is the total time from feature start to production deployment. Process time is only the time spent actively working (coding, testing, deploying). The difference is wait time. This matters because most lead time (often 80-90%) is spent waiting, not working, which represents waste and opportunity for improvement.
q13.minimum_for_full_credit: Distinguishes lead time from process time and explains why it matters
